In M&A news CenterPoint Energy (CNP) expressed interest in purchasing Vectren (VVC) for roughly USD 6bln to diversify its consumer base, Subsea 7 Made an unsolicited offer for McDermott (MDR) stating it would offer USD 2bln, which would potentially break up the deal with Chicago Bridge & Iron. Elsewhere, Newell Brands (NWL) entered an agreement with Starboard to end a proxy content. SPX 0.01% at 2670, NDX -0.28% at 6649, DJI 0.06% at 24449.

US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 7 ticks lower at 119-10+.  Treasuries closed modestly lower on the day, amid quiet trade, with most of the action concentrated on the front end and belly of the curve, with both 5s30s and 2s30s widening by c.2bp. The 10-year Treasury yield is consolidating a shade beneath 3.00% amid growing debt supply and faster inflation, printing recent highs at 2.9980 the highest since January 2014.

content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks down, USD up, treasuries down, oil up * REAR-VIEW: Trump tweet on NAFTA, potential sanctions relief on Rusal, Sohn Conference * AHEAD: Australian CPI, German Ifo Survey, Verizon, Coca-Cola and 3M earnings
* TRADE WARS: Immigration was back in the spotlight on Monday, after US President Trump tweeted “Mexico, whose laws on immigration are very tough, must stop people from going through Mexico and into the U.S. We may make this a condition of the new NAFTA Agreement. Our Country cannot accept what is happening! Also, we must get Wall funding fast.” In response, Mexico Foreign Minister Videgaray said it was unacceptable to condition NAFTA on the immigration issue. Earlier on Monday, Mexican President Nieto expressed hopes for a new NAFTA deal agreement soon. 
* GEOPOLITICS:  North Korean leader Kim on Monday confirmed the nation has suspended missile tests, adding that he is looking to shut down one of its nuclear sites. US President Trump is likely to clarify that nuclear dismantling North Korea must precede economic benefits although a senior administration official also stated that North Korea will have to earn lifting of sanctions, according to the WSJ noted, a line that was also alluded to by White House officials too. Separately, BBC sources noted Saudi air defence units intercepted two ballistic missiles which were fired by Houthi military towards Aramco facility in Jazan. Elsewhere, focus will be on French PM Macron’s meeting Trump over the Iran nuclear accord, which has been a key plank of western policy for containing military tensions in the Middle East.  
* FEDSPEAK: Fed's Williams (voter, hawkish) noted significant trade war would have very negative economic effects, adding that removal of extraordinary measures should be very gradual and with no quick changes. Williams also told Spanish newspaper ABC that the Fed can continue to lift rates without revealing new information.  
* EQUITIES: SPX 0.01% at 2670, NDX -0.28% at 6649, DJI 0.06% at 24449  SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY):  +0.33%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.10%, ENERGY (XLE): +0.64%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -0.08%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.37%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.12%, MATERIALS (XLB): 0.38%, TECH (XLK): -0.44%, TELECOMS (XTL): +1.07%, UTILITIES (XLU): +0.08%.  
Stocks opened higher but slipped into negative territory as rising bond yields pushed investors away from equities and overshadowing earnings optimism. The tech sector was the laggard in all three major indices immediately followed by the metal bloc (X, AKS, AA, ARNC) which suffered major losses following the announcement of possible Rusal’s sanctions relief. In M&A news CenterPoint Energy (CNP) expressed interest in purchasing Vectren (VVC) for roughly USD 6bln to diversify its consumer base, Subsea 7 Made an unsolicited offer for McDermott (MDR) stating it would offer USD 2bln, which would potentially break up the deal with Chicago Bridge & Iron. Elsewhere, Newell Brands (NWL) entered an agreement with Starboard to end a proxy content.  
* CRUDE: WTI futures settle up 24 cents at USD 68.64/bbl, Brent futures settle up 65 cents at USD 74.71/bbl. Oil prices were weaker in early US trade, despite weekend news that Libya output had fallen by 80k BPD due to militants attacks in Waha (Es Sider and Ras Lanuf have now resumed loading operations). The crude complex was pressured by the news that the US could relieve sanctions on Russia’s Rusal, in another sign that the US may not have the appetite to follow through with aggressive rhetoric, helping to deflate some of the geopolitical premium in crude prices. Shortly afterwards, the Iranian oil minister suggested that if crude prices continued to rise, there might not be a need to extend the current OPEC+ supply cut deal, which runs through the end of the year, compounding losses. However, later in the session, crude gradually pared back losses as it appeared that the US was still entertaining the notion of withdrawing from the Iran accord, as was argued by White House Legislative Director Short. In other news, Iran suggested that it would be prepared to do whatever necessary to counter Donald Trump and protect its oil interests, while also noting the fall in the Iran’s March crude and condensate exports was only temporary (currently stands at 2.5mln bpd). Separately, Iraqi official said that the country is hitting its oil inventory target, which is moving toward the 5-year average, in line with comments from OPEC SecGen Barkindo over the weekend. Iraqi oil minister also added that higher oil prices were not always in its benefit.  
* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 7 ticks lower at 119-10+.  Treasuries closed modestly lower on the day, amid quiet trade, with most of the action concentrated on the front end and belly of the curve, with both 5s30s and 2s30s widening by c.2bp. The 10-year Treasury yield is consolidating a shade beneath 3.00% amid growing debt supply and faster inflation, printing recent highs at 2.9980 the highest since January 2014. 
* FOREX: DXY Forming a firm foothold above the 90.500 level and the first line of resistance above in the 90.600 area as the Greenback extends gains vs G10 rivals, other majors and EM currencies. The psychological 90.750 level is now being tested even though the 10 year US Treasury has not quite printed 3%, and the next upside technical level is 90.932 ahead of 91.000. JPY/AUD/NZD The biggest losers vs a resurgent Dollar, with USDJPY finally tripping stops between 108.25-30 to seriously test a key fib just shy of 108.50 around 108.44 amidst more dovish BoJ rhetoric from Governor Kuroda ahead of Friday’s policy meeting. AUDUSD has fallen to a fresh 2018 low around 0.7615 and only barriers plus sentimentality at 0.7600 stands between here and a steeper reversal from 0.7800+ peaks only registered last week. Nzd/Usd is only just holding above 0.7150 amidst its own fall from grace having been up to 0.7400 earlier this month. Ahead RBA’s Kent may offer the Aud some respite or at least independent direction. CAD/EUR/GBP Ranging between 0.40.5% softer vs the USD, with the Loonie not just a victim of the broad Greenback rally, but also undermined by more 

 disappointing Canadian data and this time a huge miss (wholesale trade -0.8% vs forecasts ranging from 0.3-0.6%. Note, BoC’s Poloz and Wilkins speak later with USDCAD testing resistance just below 1.2850. EURUSD looks in danger of losing grip of the 1.2200 handle, if the 1.2215 April low so far and 100 DMA at 1.2205 give way, while Cable has little in terms of technical props before 1.3900 now that 1.4000 and 1.3950 have both been breached to the downside.

Fixed Income: bond bears sated, but bulls remain ragged
content: For all intents and purposes the benchmark 10 year UST yield has reached 3%, and certainly when rounding to any reasonable degree. However, this has not prompted much in the way of retracement or follow-through leaving core debt futures and cash bonds poised at or very close to pivotal levels, awaiting input from US participants for the next big move. Bunds have bounced around 20 ticks off the 157.62 low, Gilts are 10-15 ticks above the 121.12 Liffe base and then T-note future is 4 ticks from the 119-065 overnight trough, which in turn is only a couple of ticks away from the next downside chart support. On that note, Bund bears will be eyeing 157.34 and Gilt sellers 121.04. Similar story in FX, where the Usd and index has crossed several key/big figure lines, but braced for more direction.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US 10 year treasury ticking towards 3.00% yield
  • Upward pressure on the USD pushing down commodities
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US existing homes sales, ECB’s Coeure and BoC’s Poloz

 

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week lacklustre after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where all majors declined on continued tech weakness and losses in Apple amid concerns regarding iPhone demand. However, overnight pressure was contained in the Asia-Pac region amid a further improvement of the geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula after North Korea announced it will stop nuclear and ICBM testing, as well as begin dismantling a nuclear test site in the north of the country. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were mixed with weakness in Japan the result of last week’s flows into JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.5%) were choppy amid a lack of drivers and a neutral position by the PBoC which injected CNY 80bln via reverse repos to match maturing operations, although underperformance was observed in Hong Kong names. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spill over selling from USTs and as yields tracked the upside in their US counterparts, in which the US 10yr yield printed its highest since January 2014.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3034 (Prev. 6.2897)

Bank of Japan has shown signs it is tapering its ETF purchases in order to trim what it sees as an outsize profile in the equity market. (Nikkei)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said the Bank of Japan must continue very strong accommodative monetary policy for some time in order to reach 2% inflation. (CNBC)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Williams (voter, hawkish) said significant trade war would have very negative economic effects; adding that removal of extraordinary measures should be very gradual and with no quick changes. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean leader Kim said North Korea has suspended missile tests and is to shut down one of their nuclear sites. (BBC)

US President Trump is expected to tell North Korea leader Kim that nuclear dismantling must precede economic benefits, while a senior administration official also stated that North Korea will have to earn lifting of sanctions. (WSJ)

EU/UK/US

UK government insisted that the UK will leave the EU customs union and are said to have reassured Eurosceptic Conservative Party MPs after weekend reports suggested UK may have to remain in the customs union post-Brexit. (Telegraph)

EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Apr) 55.2 vs. Exp. 54.9 (Prev. 55.2)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Apr) 56.0 vs. Exp. 56.6 (Prev. 56.6)

EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Apr) 55.0 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.9)

EQUITIES

European equities opened on the back foot this morning (Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%) following the dampened tone from Asia. Switzerland’s SMI is underperforming as index heavyweight UBS (-3.1%) lags following earnings. Sector wise, consumer staples underperform while Reckitt Benckiser (-2.2%) are at the bottom of the FTSE 100 following a downgrade at Raymond James and a target price cut at JP Morgan. In terms of stocks specifics, Fresenius (+0.6%) shares are higher following the terminations of the Akorn merger amid data breaches. Fresenius Medical (-3.6%) is at the foot of the DAX 30 following a revenue target cut for this year. Capita (+10.1%) is the best performing in the Stoxx 600 following earnings and reports the company is to raise GBP 701mln in a 3 for 2 rights issue entirely underwritten by Citigroup and Goldman Sachs.

FX

USD

Firmer US rates are certainly fuelling the latest Dollar revival and the Greenback’s broad gains, but latest conciliatory noises from NK on the nuclear front are also undermining the traditional safe-haven currencies. The index is now comfortably above 90.500 and 90.600 resistance, looking at 90.750 next.

JPY/EUR

Both on the brink of breaking out of recent ranges, with Usd/Jpy up through 108.00 offers, a big barrier and resistance extending to 108.20, but capped just ahead of stops reportedly lying between 108.25-30, while Eur/Usd has breached last Friday’s 1.2250 low having failed to reach 1.2300 in wake of better than forecast Eurozone flash PMIs, and is now also below the next downside technical support level at 1.2235, eyeing 1.2200

CHF/NZD/AUD

All around 0.25% down vs the Dollar, with Usd/Chf around 0.9770, Nzd/Usd sub-0.7200 and Aud/Usd down through the previous YtD low (0.7643) amidst at least 2 bearish big bank ‘trades of the week’. The latter pair will be eyeing 0.7620-15, which is the 2016 base before barriers said to be waiting at 0.7600.

CAD

Usd/Cad looks is revisiting 1.2800+ on the aforementioned supportive Greenback narrative and contrasting Loonie weights in the form of last Friday’s CPI data and a still cautious BoC, although latest NAFTA reports indicate a deal could be reached in early May. The range has been 1.2750-1.2805, and the recent peak is circa 1.2820 (February 9).

GBP

Losing traction around the 1.4000 level after last week’s heavy losses on a mixture of UK data misses and dovish or less hawkish BoE policy guidance from Governor Carney. Looking to test chart support around 1.3960 while Eur/Gbp is nudging up towards the high of a 0.8745-75 range.

EM

Try, Rub and Zar markedly underperforming amidst the higher US Treasury yield environment and with regional political factors also a drag on the Rand in particular. However the Mxn may derive support from latest reports on NAFTA, with the Mexican President saying a deal would come soon.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt on the back foot, with the 10 year benchmark initially down 15 ticks on its return to Liffe then succumbing to additional selling pressure and a 121.12 low vs the 121.52 previous settlement after staging a relatively firm rebound to 121.47 at best. Gilts look somewhat caught between the overall bearish tone in fixed and especially US Treasuries, but a less hawkish near term BoE outlook following last week’s run of disappointing data, on balance. Hence, the UK STIR strip is seeing more short end outperformance/resilience vs the back months a tick or so either side of parity, and in fact Gilts are holding up better than core bond counterparts, as the 10 year Treasury yield inches ever closer to 3% while Bunds have posted a deeper Eurex session base at 157.62 (-51 ticks) amidst firmer than forecast Eurozone flash PMIs.

COMMODITIES

Oil prices dipping in Monday trade with WTI down 0.6% at USD 68/bbl. This follows Baker Hughes reporting an increased rig count on Friday, which is now at its highest level since March 2015, suggesting increased US production putting downward pressure on the fossil fuel, as well as tweets from the US President suggesting oil is “artificially high” due to OPEC. The strengthening dollar is also weighing on gold with the yellow metal down 0.5% on the day. Some OPEC specific news coming from the Azerbaijani energy minister who says the country joining OPEC is not on the agenda.

Morning EU Movers:  Capita (CPI LN) +8.1%, Philips (PHIA NA) +3.3%, Fresenius (FRE GY) +2.7% Whitbread (WTB LN) +1.6%, Air France (AF FP) -1.5%, UBS (UBSG SW) -3.3%, Reckitt Benckiser (RB/ LN) -3.5%
Chinese Politburo says they will push for the healthy development of FX, stocks, debt, credit and property markets
German Engineering trade body VDMA raises 2018 output growth forecast to 5% vs. 3%, driven especially by exports, adds that exports to Britain could fall by 2 digit percentage due to Brexit
Bunds: lurching lower and chasing down US Treasuries
content: Heavy corrective trade off Monday’s Eurex open, as core debt continues to respond to less angst on the geopolitical front and in some quarters on global trade wars – although relations between the US and China/Russia remain frosty or fragile at best. Bunds gapped down through the 158.00 level from the off, to 157.88 and extended losses from last Friday’s 158.13 close to 34 ticks at 157.79 before consolidating and probing back up towards the figure. Aside from broad risk sentiment, flash PMIs in focus along with a speech from ECB’s Coeure that is unusually close to Thursday’s policy meeting, but may contain something pertinent. The 10 year German benchmark just off a 157.97 rebound high ahead of the EU cash bourse opens.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Deutsche Bank, BMW, and Volkswagen
content:
23rd April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week lacklustre after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where all majors declined on continued tech weakness and losses in Apple amid concerns regarding iPhone demand. However, overnight pressure was contained in the Asia-Pac region amid a further improvement of the geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula after North Korea announced it will stop nuclear and ICBM testing, as well as begin dismantling a nuclear test site in the north of the country. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were mixed with weakness in Japan the result of last week’s flows into JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.3%) were choppy amid a lack of drivers and a neutral position by the PBoC which injected CNY 80bln via reverse repos to match maturing operations, although underperformance was observed in Hong Kong names.

FTSE

Vodafone (VOD LN) / Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) - A plan to buy Liberty Global's (LBTYA) German and Eastern European networks for about EUR 16.5bln is within the final stages and could be agreed within the next two weeks. This would put them in direct competition with Deutsche Telekom. (FT)

WPP (WPP LN) - Ford (F) has put parts of its advertising account up for review in the next few weeks. This deals a blow to its current agency WPP. (WSJ)

Capita (CPI LN) - Investors have increased short positions vs. the co. days before they are to deliver a strategy update, these positions have put the co. within the top 20 most traded stocks on the London market. (Times)

Whitbread (WTB LN) - The co.'s Alison Brittain believes a break up between the groups coffee and hotel businesses is inevitable. (Sunday Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

De La Rue (DLAR LN) / Gemalto (GTA NA) - De La Rue has come under fire by Crystal Amber, who have said the company mishandled the awarding of UK passports to Gemalto, and had made itself a takeover target. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

RECKITT BENCKISER (RB/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT RAYMOND JAMES

MARKS AND SPENCER (MKS LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK) – Multiple members from the supervisory board voted ‘no’ at the April 8th meeting over reshuffling management. Separately, Chinese conglomerate HNA cuts stake in Co. to 7.9%, down 10.4% since February. (Newswires/FT)

German Autonames - The European Commission is moving towards an intensification of its antitrust probe of German Automakers, meaning fines may be more likely. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) - The co. is planning to make more stores in city centers, so as to make the brand more visible. (Newswires)

Fresenius (FRE GY) - The co. says it has decided to pull out of its planned purchase of Akorn (AKRX), after data breaches were found. (Newswires)

Fresenius Medical (FME GY) - The co. cuts it revenue target for the year as a result of lower than expected doses of calcimimetic drugs at its dialysis service business in the US. Further the co. also said it would sell its majority shareholding in Sound Inpatient Physicians Holdings for USD 2.15bln. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - CEO said the company has a fresh determination to sell its Ducati unit. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – Co. is predicting 25% of flights will be cancelled on Monday, the 10th strike day by staff over wages. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ILIAD (ILD FP) DOWNGRADED FROM EQUAL WEIGHT TO UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SMI

UBS (UBSG SW) - Co. says Q1 net profit attributable to shareholders CHF 1.514bln vs. exp. CHF 1.373bln, and adj. pre-tax profit reported as CHF 1.876bln vs exp. 1.831bln. Previously announced share buyback will commence in Q2. The co. says they remain confident despite threats coming from geopolitics and protectionism. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

Gemalto (GTO NA) – Co. awarded a multi-year service contract for new British passports. The contract is for 11 and a half years which includes 10 years of production and issuance services. (Newswires)

Philips (PHIA NA) – Q1 sales EUR 3.90bln. vs. Exp. EUR 3.92bln. Q1 EBITA EUR 263mln vs. EUR 212mln. Co. reiterates targets for 2017/2018. (Newswires)    

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) - Activist investor Elliott International has hired broker Equita SIM to help win the battle over investors for control over the Italian telecoms company. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Tele2 (TELE2B SS) – Q1 sales SEK 6.22bln vs. Exp. SEK 6.11bln. Q1 EBITDA SEK 1.63bln vs. Exp. SEK 1.62bln. Co. aims for ordinary dividend of at least 80% of equity free cash flow post Com Hem (COMH SS) merger. Co. reiterates guidance for 2018 for continuing operations in constant currencies. Co. sees first signs of gradual B2B revenues stabilisation in Sweden. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.9% at 2670, NDX -1.6% at 6666, DJI -0.8% at 24467.

SECTORS: Consumer cyclicals -1.1%, consumer non-cyclicals -1.7%, energy -0.6%, financials -0.2%, healthcare -0.6%, industrials -0.5%, materials -0.8%, tech -1.5%, telecoms -1.2%, utilities -1.0%. TODAY’S ACTION: Futures were trading sub-2700 pre-cash open, and sank after the cash day got underway, with AAPL weighing. While stocks were lower on the day, ESM8 contract is pretty-much flat on the week.

subject: Fed's Williams (voter, hawkish) says significant trade war would have very negative economic effects; adding that removal of extraordinary measures should be very gradual and with no quick changes
Daily European Opening News: 23rd April 2018 - Now available in the Research Suite
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities mixed as markets digest latest news from North Korea
  • USD remained firm, underpinned by higher US yields
  • Looking ahead highlights include Eurozone flash PMIs, US existing homes sales, ECB’s Coeure and BoC’s Poloz

 

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week lacklustre after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where all majors declined on continued tech weakness and losses in Apple amid concerns regarding iPhone demand. However, overnight pressure was contained in the Asia-Pac region amid a further improvement of the geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula after North Korea announced it will stop nuclear and ICBM testing, as well as begin dismantling a nuclear test site in the north of the country. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were mixed with weakness in Japan the result of last week’s flows into JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.3%) were choppy amid a lack of drivers and a neutral position by the PBoC which injected CNY 80bln via reverse repos to match maturing operations, although underperformance was observed in Hong Kong names. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spill over selling from USTs and as yields tracked the upside in their US counterparts, in which the US 10yr yield printed its highest since January 2014.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3034 (Prev. 6.2897)

Bank of Japan has shown signs it is tapering its ETF purchases in order to trim what it sees as an outsize profile in the equity market. (Nikkei)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said the Bank of Japan must continue very strong accommodative monetary policy for some time in order to reach 2% inflation. (CNBC)

UK

UK government insisted that the UK will leave the EU customs union and are said to have reassured Eurosceptic Conservative Party MPs after weekend reports suggested UK may have to remain in the customs union post-Brexit. (Telegraph)

Note: There were initial reports over the weekend that Senior Brexiteers are said to be concerned and have warned that PM may is supporting a hybrid plan for post-Brexit relationship with EU that would make trade deals with other countries impossible and in which the UK would collect customs duties on EU’s behalf for goods to the EU. (Telegraph) Furthermore, UK PM May’s team was said to have privately admitted that the UK may have to accept permanent membership of a European customs union. (Times)

EU

Sources reported that ECB normalisation path has not been affected by the recent string of soft data and stated that QE is still to end by the end of 2018. (Newswires)


ECB’s Villeroy (dovish) said despite a slowdown in Q1 growth, there will be a solid or improved economic recovery in France during upcoming 2 or 3 years. (Newswires)


Fitch upgraded Cyprus to 'BB+'; Outlook Positive. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the greenback remained firm and the DXY held above 90.00 as its major counterparts languished from recent losses with EUR/USD below 1.2300, while GBP/USD found mild support at the 1.4000 level but still has some distance to recoup the lost ground after BoE Governor Carney placed doubts on a May hike last week. AUD, NZD and CAD were subdued amid similar price action in commodities with CAD despondent from softer than expected CPI data, while JPY remained mostly firmer with JPY-crosses near last week’s lows although USD/JPY bucked the trend and was driven by USD outperformance.

Mexico Central Bank Governor Diaz de Leon said that MXN weakness does not require intervention. In separate news, Mexico have signed a free trade agreement with the EU in which the new agreement expands into sectors including finance, e-commerce and agriculture. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were quiet overnight with WTI crude prices rangebound following last week’s OPEC meeting in which the monitoring committee refrained from any new recommendations. Elsewhere, gold was also lacklustre and marginally extended on last Friday’s declines amid a firmer greenback, while copper prices traded higher and found support amid gains in Chinese metal prices.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (20 Apr) 1013 (Prev. 1008). (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said that there is no price objective to OPEC or in a deal with non-OPEC members and highlighted the objective is to restore stability. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said not in the business of managing oil prices. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean leader Kim said North Korea has suspended missile tests and is to shut down one of their nuclear sites. (BBC)

US President Trump is expected to tell North Korea leader Kim that nuclear dismantling must precede economic benefits, while a senior administration official also stated that North Korea will have to earn lifting of sanctions. (WSJ)

South Korea said it stopped propaganda broadcasts at the border with North Korea, while South Korea is also beginning the preparation of an inter-Korean economic cooperation plan. (Newswires)

G7 meeting contained good discussion regarding US-North Korea tensions, while there was unity in opposing Russian behaviour of destabilizing nations and they also discussed Iran's malign activity and unacceptable nuclear ballistic missile program. (Newswires)

Iran President Rouhani has threated “expected and unexpected” reactions if the US exits the nuclear agreement. (Newswires)

US

It was another day of bear-steepening on Friday with shorter dated yields rising by under 2bps, and long end yields higher by just over 3bps at settlement. But while the steepening curve was attributed for part of the jitters in stocks on Friday, actual curve spreads only saw modest widening (2s30s was were most of the action was at and was only steeper by c.2bps). In post-settlement trade, the 10yr note rose to near 2.96%, reaching levels last seen in 2014. US 10yr T-Notes futures settles 9 ticks lower at 119-17+.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US is continuing dialogue with China and are cautiously optimistic on reaching an agreement. Mnuchin added he may possibly visit China, although he suggested that nothing was confirmed and that it was being considered. (Newswires)

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dovish) reiterated view on gradual hikes and said that the economy is solid but noted uncertainties around the outlook given international trade. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said neutral rate appears much lower than in the past and that he expects 'new normal' for Fed's balance sheet to be around USD 3trln. Furthermore, Williams said that stronger global growth lifts demand for US exports which helps to reduce disinflationary pressures. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dovish) said if inflation rises faster than expected it is a sign of a stronger economy that can withstand further rate increases, while he added that gradual rate hikes continue to be appropriate. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dovish) is said to be surprised the long-end of the curve has risen further after fiscal stimulus and is also surprised by the flatness of the yield curve, which he said warrants caution. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins the week lacklustre after Friday's continued tech losses, although downside is contained on further improvement of geopolitical climate
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week lacklustre after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where all majors declined on continued tech weakness and losses in Apple amid concerns regarding iPhone demand. However, overnight pressure is also contained in the Asia-Pac region amid a further improvement of the geopolitical climate in the Korean peninsula after North Korea announced it will stop nuclear and ICBM testing, as well as begin dismantling a nuclear test site in the north of the country. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) are mixed with weakness in Japan the result of last week’s flows into JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) is choppy amid a lack of any major drivers and a neutral position by the PBoC which injected CNY 80bln via reverse repos to match maturing operations, while the Hang Seng (-0.5%) underperforms on tech-related declines.

In FX markets, the greenback remains firm and the DXY above 90.00 as its major counterparts languish from recent losses with EUR/USD below 1.2300, while GBP/USD finds mild support at the 1.4000 level but still has some distance to recoup the lost ground after BoE Governor Carney placed doubts on a May hike last week. AUD, NZD and CAD are subdued amid similar price action in the commodities complex and with CAD despondent from softer than expected CPI data, while JPY remains mostly firmer with JPY-crosses near last week’s lows although USD/JPY bucks the trend and is driven by USD outperformance.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid spill over selling from USTs and with yields tracking the upside in their US counterparts, which saw the US 10yr print its highest since January 2014 in early Asia trade.
